Blubbering Clementine Gallery 623 West 27th Street, Chelsea Through April 21

''Blubbering,'' a collection of Neil Farber's latest mixed-media works on paper, brings to mind Dante's ''Divine Comedy.'' But instead of focusing on the experience of hell and purgatory in the afterlife, Mr. Farber takes on the madness of contemporary civilization.

He is a founding member of the mostly male Royal Art Lodge, an art collective based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, that since 1996 has gathered regularly to create drawings, videos and puppet shows. Their most famous member is Marcel Dzama, whose drawings of mythical creatures, both humanoid and animal, recall Henry Darger's strange forays into male psychosexual fantasies.

Mr. Farber is also concerned with male troubles, but he demonstrates a keen interest in paint's expressive qualities. Take his picture of a sea of male heads made from blobs of gesso the size of a thumbtack: their hardheadedness enhances the picture's sense that the march toward civilization is aimless. In his picture of a decapitated man and howling dogs, the gushing blood is created by red paint let loose in resin and left to dry, so it looks as if the bleeding will never stop.

The show's pièce de résistance is a contemporary update of Hieronymus Bosch's painting ''Ship of Fools.'' Bosch portrayed the world as falling apart amid human debauchery; Mr. Farber shows a group of men going down in a sinking ship, drowned by the weight of their own neurosis (the exact nature of which is written in tiny script across the sky). Hell, it seems, is not somewhere else, but in the reality you create for yourself.
